H0.text: The molecules spread apart and move more slowly after heat is applied to a beaker of water, raising the water temperature a few degrees.

H1.text: The molecules spread apart and move more quickly when heat is applied to a beaker of water, raising its temperature a few degrees.

H2.text: The molecules come together and move more slowly after heat is applied to a beaker of water, raising the water temperature a few degrees.

H3.text: The molecules come together and move more quickly when heat is applied to a beaker of water, raising its temperature a few degrees.

A4.text: The translational motion of the particle has three degrees of freedom, so that, except at very low temperatures where quantum effects predominate, the average translational kinetic energy of a freely moving particle in a system with temperature T will be 3kBT/2.

A5.text: Heating results in an increase of temperature due to an increase in the average translational kinetic energy of the molecules.
